awd_titl_txt: EAGER: BRAIDING: Majorana modes in monolayer topological insulator WTe2
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Abstract: Finding alternative paths to quantum computing is paramount at this time, and current approaches face many hurdles. The biggest is decoherence of the qubits, meaning that the quantum information content decays exponentially with time. In principle, decoherence can be avoided using "topological protection". The only realistic known scheme for topological protection is based on creating the qubits from so-called Majorana modes, which are peculiar states that occur at the ends of certain types of quantum wires. One way to make Majoranas is using the special quantum wire that exists at the edge of a topological insulator. The PI, an experimentalist, recently discovered the first natural monolayer two-dimensional (2D) topological insulator, suggesting the possibility to create and manipulate Majoranas in 2D materials. The co-PI is a theorist and expert on topological phenomena; in this project they collaborate to find the simplest way to create and detect Majoranas in this system. The work supports graduate students in topical interdisciplinary work where theory and experiment go hand in hand, and which could conceivably give birth to the next information revolution. The project forms a bridge between the University of Washington, which has a leading research effort in 2D materials, and local industry (including Microsoft) which is investing heavily in applications of quantum computers.

Technical: This project aims to establish the viability of the 2D materials platform for creating Majorana zero modes that could be used for topological quantum processing. The team employs monolayer WTe2 as a 2D topological insulator, combined with a 2D superconductor (NbSe2 or FeSe) and a 2D magnet (CrI3 or CrBr3). These materials are stacked into a van der Waals heterostructure along with electrical contacts and tunnel barriers. At the point where the three materials meet a Majorana mode may appear at low temperatures and can be probed by tunneling measurements. This 2D platform offers advantages compared with other Majorana systems including that no magnetic field is required to produce the helical mode, and the possibility to avoid delicate tuning of the chemical potential. The complexity of the many-electron and topological physics involved, and the novelty of the system, calls for close cooperation between experiment and theory. Specific goals are to induce and understand a superconducting proximity gap in the helical edge of WTe2, and to design and test the simplest 2D possible heterostructure devices in which Majoranas may occur and be detected.

por.por_cntn:
In this project the main goal was to evaluate the potential of a particular material, monolayer WTe2, to provide a base for creating Majorana modes, which are not only fascinating in their own right but could in the future be employed as components of topologically protected qubits. To create such modes it is necessary to show that there exists a “helical” (spin-momentum-locked) quantum wire on any edge of the material, and then to induce somehow both a magnetic exchange gap and a superconducting gap in different parts of the wire. The modes could then be detected by tunneling measurements. Our two main findings were as follows.

First, we established that the edge modes on monolayer WTe2 are indeed helical, by showing that their conductance is suppressed by a magnetic field oriented perpendicular to a particular axis relative to the crystal structure. We identified this axis as the spin axis, and realized by theoretical reasoning that the very same axis describes the spin-orbit coupling in the bulk bands as well as in the edges (see first figure). This profound insight into the spin texture offers opportunities for controlling the spin and is relevant to proposed unconventional superconductivity in this material.

Second, when we placed monolayer WTe2 in contact with a two-dimensional (2D) layered insulating magnetic material, CrI3, we observed that the edge conduction was suppressed in a manner consistent with induced scattering due to magnetic exchange inherited by the edges states from the magnet. This is evident as the disappearance of the residual edge conduction at low temperatures (see second figure). Also, at moderate temperatures the edge conduction depended on the magnetic state of the CrI3, even when the CrI3 was antiferromagnetic and had no net magnetization, implying that the exchange was dominated by coupling to the single layer of CrI3 in contact with the WTe2. These results both count as steps towards the Majorana goal. Unless and until we succeed in inducing a superconducting gap in the edge state, though, this goal will be blocked.

2D topological insulators were the first kind of topologically nontrivial material to be hypothesized to exist, and the almost irrefutable evidence for spin-momentum locking in WTe2 provided above demonstrates that such exotic materials really exist in nature. The new physics that arises in these materials could have wide-ranging consequences and unforeseen applications.
